name: dart-io
comment:
File, socket, HTTP, and other I/O support for server applications.

The I/O library is used for Dart server applications, which run on a stand-alone Dart VM from the command line. This library does not work in browser-based applications.

This library allows you to work with files, directories, sockets, processes, HTTP servers and clients, and more.

To use this library in your code:

import 'dart:io';

Note: Many operations related to input and output are asynchronous and are handled using dart-async.Futures or dart-async.Streams, both of which are defined in the dart:async library.

File, Directory, and Link

An instance of dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, or dart-io.Link represents a file, directory, or link, respectively, in the native file system.

You can manipulate the file system through objects of these types. For example, you can rename a file or directory:

File myFile = new File('myFile.txt');
myFile.rename('yourFile.txt').then((_) => print('file renamed'));

Many methods provided by the File, Directory, and Link classes run asynchronously and return a Future.

FileSystemEntity

File, Directory, and Link all extend dart-io.FileSystemEntity. In addition to being the superclass for these classes, FileSystemEntity has a number of static methods for working with paths.

To get information about a path, you can use the FileSystemEntity static methods such as 'isDirectory', 'isFile', and 'exists'. Because file system access involves I/O, these methods are asynchronous and return a Future.

FileSystemEntity.isDirectory(myPath).then((isDir) {
  if (isDir) {
    print('$myPath is a directory');
  } else {
    print('$myPath is not a directory');
  }
});

HttpServer and HttpClient

The classes dart-io.HttpServer and dart-io.HttpClient provide HTTP server and HTTP client functionality.

The dart-io.HttpServer class provides the basic functionality for implementing an HTTP server. For some higher-level building-blocks, we recommend that you try the http_server pub package, which contains a set of high-level classes that, together with the dart-io.HttpServer class in this library, make it easier to implement HTTP servers.

Process

The dart-io.Process class provides a way to run a process on the native machine. For example, the following code spawns a process that recursively lists the files under web.

Process.start('ls', ['-R', 'web']).then((process) {
  stdout.addStream(process.stdout);
  stderr.addStream(process.stderr);
  process.exitCode.then(print);
});

Using start() returns a Future, which completes with a dart-io.Process object when the process has started. This dart-io.Process object allows you to interact with the process while it is running. Using run() returns a Future, which completes with a dart-io.ProcessResult object when the spawned process has terminated. This dart-io.ProcessResult object collects the output and exit code from the process.

When using start(), you need to read all data coming on the stdout and stderr streams otherwise the system resources will not be freed.

WebSocket

The dart-io.WebSocket class provides support for the web socket protocol. This allows full-duplex communications between client and server applications. Use the WebSocket class in the dart:html library for web clients.

A web socket server uses a normal HTTP server for accepting web socket connections. The initial handshake is a HTTP request which is then upgraded to a web socket connection. The server upgrades the request using dart-io.WebSocketTransformer and listens for the data on the returned web socket. For example, here's a mini server that listens for 'ws' data on a WebSocket:

runZoned(() {
  HttpServer.bind('127.0.0.1', 4040).then((server) {
    server.listen((HttpRequest req) {
      if (req.uri.path == '/ws') {
        WebSocketTransformer.upgrade(req).then((socket) {
          socket.listen(handleMsg);
        });
      }
    });
  });
},
onError: (e) => print("An error occurred."));

The client connects to the WebSocket using the connect() method and a URI that uses the Web Socket protocol. The the client can write to the WebSocket with the add() method. For example,

WebSocket.connect('ws://127.0.0.1:4040/ws').then((socket) {
  socket.add('Hello, World!');
});

Check out the dartiverse_search sample for a client/server pair that uses WebSockets to communicate.

Socket and ServerSocket

Clients and servers use dart-io.Sockets to communicate using the TCP protocol. Use dart-io.ServerSocket on the server side and dart-io.Socket on the client. The server creates a listening socket using the bind() method and then listens for incoming connections on the socket. For example:

ServerSocket.bind('127.0.0.1', 4041)
  .then((serverSocket) {
    serverSocket.listen((socket) {
      socket.transform(UTF8.decoder).listen(print);
    });
  });

A client connects a Socket using the connect() method, which returns a Future. Using write(), writeln(), or writeAll() are the easiest ways to send data over the socket. For example:

Socket.connect('127.0.0.1', 4041).then((socket) {
  socket.write('Hello, World!');
});

Besides dart-io.Socket and dart-io.ServerSocket, the dart-io.RawSocket and dart-io.RawServerSocket classes are available for lower-level access to async socket IO.

Standard output, error, and input streams

This library provides the standard output, error, and input streams, named 'stdout', 'stderr', and 'stdin', respectively.

The stdout and stderr streams are both dart-io.IOSinks and have the same set of methods and properties.

To write a string to 'stdout':

stdout.writeln('Hello, World!');

To write a list of objects to 'stderr':

stderr.writeAll([ 'That ', 'is ', 'an ', 'error.', '\n']);

The standard input stream is a true dart-async.Stream, so it inherits properties and methods from the Stream class.

To read text synchronously from the command line (the program blocks waiting for user to type information):

 String inputText = stdin.readLineSync();

Other resources

For an introduction to I/O in Dart, see the dart:io section of the library tour.

To learn more about I/O in Dart, refer to the tutorial about writing command-line apps.

APPEND.name: APPEND
APPEND.comment: The mode for opening a file for reading and writing to the end of it. The file is created if it does not already exist.

WRITE.name: WRITE
WRITE.comment: The mode for opening a file for reading and writing. The file is overwritten if it already exists. The file is created if it does not already exist.

READ.name: READ
READ.comment: The mode for opening a file only for reading.

GZIP.name: GZIP
GZIP.comment: An instance of the default implementation of the dart-io.GZipCodec.

ZLIB.name: ZLIB
ZLIB.comment: An instance of the default implementation of the dart-io.ZLibCodec.

exitCode=.name: exitCode=
exitCode=.comment:
Set the global exit code for the Dart VM.

The exit code is global for the Dart VM and the last assignment to exitCode from any isolate determines the exit code of the Dart VM on normal termination.

Default value is 0.

See dart-io.exit for more information on how to chose a value for the exit code.

stderr.name: stderr
stderr.comment: The standard output stream of errors written by this program.

stdout.name: stdout
stdout.comment: The standard output stream of data written by this program.

stdin.name: stdin
stdin.comment: The standard input stream of data read by this program.

pid.name: pid
pid.comment: Returns the PID of the current process.

stdioType.name: stdioType
stdioType.comment: For a stream, returns whether it is attached to a file, pipe, terminal, or something else.

sleep.name: sleep
sleep.comment:
Sleep for the duration specified in dart-io.sleep.duration.

Use this with care, as no asynchronous operations can be processed in a isolate while it is blocked in a dart-io.sleep call.

exit.name: exit
exit.comment:
Exit the Dart VM process immediately with the given exit code.

This does not wait for any asynchronous operations to terminate. Using dart-io.exit is therefore very likely to lose data.

The handling of exit codes is platform specific.

On Linux and Mac OS an exit code for normal termination will always be in the range 0..255. If an exit code outside this range is set the actual exit code will be the lower 8 bits masked off and treated as an unsigned value. E.g. using an exit code of -1 will result in an actual exit code of 255 being reported.

On Windows the exit code can be set to any 32-bit value. However some of these values are reserved for reporting system errors like crashes.

Besides this the Dart executable itself uses an exit code of 254 for reporting compile time errors and an exit code of 255 for reporting runtime error (unhandled exception).

Due to these facts it is recommended to only use exit codes in the range 0..127 for communicating the result of running a Dart program to the surrounding environment. This will avoid any cross-platform issues.

class.name: WebSocket
class.preview: A two-way HTTP communication object for client or server applications.

class.name: WebSocketTransformer
class.preview: The dart-io.WebSocketTransformer provides the ability to upgrade a dart-io.HttpRequest to a dart-io.WebSocket connection. It supports both upgrading a single dart-io.HttpRequest and upgrading a stream of dart-io.HttpRequests.

class.name: WebSocketStatus
class.preview: Web socket status codes used when closing a web socket connection.

class.name: RawSecureServerSocket
class.preview: The RawSecureServerSocket is a server socket, providing a stream of low-level dart-io.RawSecureSockets.

class.name: SecureServerSocket
class.preview: The dart-io.SecureServerSocket is a server socket, providing a stream of high-level dart-io.Sockets.

class.name: X509Certificate
class.preview: X509Certificate represents an SSL certificate, with accessors to get the fields of the certificate.

class.name: RawSecureSocket
class.preview: RawSecureSocket provides a secure (SSL or TLS) network connection. Client connections to a server are provided by calling RawSecureSocket.connect. A secure server, created with RawSecureServerSocket, also returns RawSecureSocket objects representing the server end of a secure connection. The certificate provided by the server is checked using the certificate database provided in SecureSocket.initialize, and/or the default built-in root certificates.

class.name: SecureSocket
class.preview: A high-level class for communicating securely over a TCP socket, using TLS and SSL. The dart-io.SecureSocket exposes both a dart-async.Stream and an dart-io.IOSink interface, making it ideal for using together with other dart-async.Streams.

class.name: SystemEncoding
class.preview: The system encoding is the current code page on Windows and UTF-8 on Linux and Mac.

class.name: StdioType
class.preview: The type of object a standard IO stream is attached to.

class.name: Stdout
class.preview: dart-io.Stdout exposes methods to query the terminal for properties.

class.name: Stdin
class.preview: dart-io.Stdin allows both synchronous and asynchronous reads from the standard input stream.

class.name: RawDatagramSocket
class.preview: The dart-io.RawDatagramSocket is a low-level interface to an UDP socket, exposing the raw events signaled by the system. It's a dart-async.Stream of dart-io.RawSocketEvents.

class.name: Datagram
class.preview: Datagram package. Data send to and received from datagram sockets contains the internet address and port of the destination or source togeter with the data.

class.name: Socket
class.preview: A high-level class for communicating over a TCP socket.

class.name: RawSocket
class.preview: The dart-io.RawSocket is a low-level interface to a socket, exposing the raw events signaled by the system. It's a dart-async.Stream of dart-io.RawSocketEvents.

class.name: RawSocketEvent
class.preview: Events for the dart-io.RawSocket.

class.name: SocketOption
class.preview: The dart-io.SocketOption is used as a parameter to dart-io.Socket.setOption and dart-io.RawSocket.setOption to set customize the behaviour of the underlying socket.

class.name: SocketDirection
class.preview: The dart-io.SocketDirection is used as a parameter to Socket.close and dart-io.RawSocket.close to close a socket in the specified direction(s).

class.name: ServerSocket
class.preview: A dart-io.ServerSocket represents a listening socket, and provides a stream of dart-io.Socket objects, one for each connection made to the listening socket.

class.name: RawServerSocket
class.preview: A dart-io.RawServerSocket represents a listening socket, and provides a stream of low-level dart-io.RawSocket objects, one for each connection made to the listening socket.

class.name: NetworkInterface
class.preview: A dart-io.NetworkInterface represent an active network interface on the current system. It contains a list of dart-io.InternetAddresss, that's bound to the interface.

class.name: InternetAddress
class.preview: An internet address.

class.name: InternetAddressType
class.preview: dart-io.InternetAddressType is the type an dart-io.InternetAddress. Currently, IP version 4 (IPv4) and IP version 6 (IPv6) are supported.

class.name: ProcessSignal
class.preview: On Posix systems, dart-io.ProcessSignal is used to send a specific signal to a child process, see Process.kill.

class.name: ProcessResult
class.preview: dart-io.ProcessResult represents the result of running a non-interactive process started with Process.run.

class.name: Process
class.preview: The means to execute a program.

class.name: Platform
class.preview: Information about the environment in which the current program is running.

class.name: Link
class.preview: dart-io.Link objects are references to filesystem links.

class.name: IOSink
class.preview: Helper class to wrap a StreamConsumer<dart-core<dart-core>> and provide utility functions for writing to the StreamConsumer directly. The dart-io.IOSink buffers the input given by all dart-core.StringSink methods and will delay an dart-io.IOSink.addStream until the buffer is flushed.

class.name: HttpDate
class.preview: Utility functions for working with dates with HTTP specific date formats.

class.name: DetachedSocket
class.preview: When detaching a socket from either the HttpServer or the HttpClient due to a HTTP connection upgrade there might be unparsed data already read from the socket. This unparsed data together with the detached socket is returned in an instance of this class.

class.name: RedirectInfo
class.preview: Redirect information.

class.name: HttpConnectionInfo
class.preview: Information about an dart-io.HttpRequest, dart-io.HttpResponse, dart-io.HttpClientRequest, or dart-io.HttpClientResponse connection.

class.name: HttpClientDigestCredentials
class.preview: Represents credentials for digest authentication. Digest authentication is only supported for servers using the MD5 algorithm and quality of protection (qop) of either "none" or "auth".

class.name: HttpClientBasicCredentials
class.preview: Represents credentials for basic authentication.

class.name: HttpClientResponse
class.preview: HTTP response for a client connection.

class.name: HttpClientRequest
class.preview: HTTP request for a client connection.

class.name: HttpClient
class.preview: A client that receives content, such as web pages, from a server using the HTTP protocol.

class.name: HttpResponse
class.preview: An HTTP response, which returns the headers and data from the server to the client in response to an HTTP request.

class.name: HttpRequest
class.preview: A server-side object that contains the content of and information about an HTTP request.

class.name: Cookie
class.preview: Representation of a cookie. For cookies received by the server as Cookie header values only name and value fields will be set. When building a cookie for the 'set-cookie' header in the server and when receiving cookies in the client as 'set-cookie' headers all fields can be used.

class.name: ContentType
class.preview: Representation of a content type. An instance of dart-io.ContentType is immutable.

class.name: HeaderValue
class.preview: Representation of a header value in the form:

class.name: HttpHeaders
class.preview: Headers for HTTP requests and responses.

class.name: HttpConnectionsInfo
class.preview: Summary statistics about an dart-io.HttpServers current socket connections.

class.name: HttpServer
class.preview: A server that delivers content, such as web pages, using the HTTP protocol.

class.name: HttpStatus
class.preview: HTTP status codes.

class.name: FileSystemMoveEvent
class.preview: File system event for moving of file system objects.

class.name: FileSystemDeleteEvent
class.preview: File system event for deletion of file system objects.

class.name: FileSystemModifyEvent
class.preview: File system event for modifications of file system objects.

class.name: FileSystemCreateEvent
class.preview: File system event for newly created file system objects.

class.name: FileSystemEvent
class.preview: Base event class emitted by dart-io.FileSystemEntity.watch.

class.name: FileSystemEntity
class.preview: The common super class for dart-io.File, dart-io.Directory, and dart-io.Link objects.

class.name: FileStat
class.preview: A FileStat object represents the result of calling the POSIX stat() function on a file system object. It is an immutable object, representing the snapshotted values returned by the stat() call.

class.name: FileSystemEntityType
class.preview: The type of an entity on the file system, such as a file, directory, or link.

class.name: RandomAccessFile
class.preview: dart-io.RandomAccessFile provides random access to the data in a file. dart-io.RandomAccessFile objects are obtained by calling the open method on a dart-io.File object.

class.name: File
class.preview: A reference to a file on the file system.

class.name: FileMode
class.preview: The modes in which a File can be opened.

class.name: Directory
class.preview: A reference to a directory (or folder) on the file system.

class.name: ZLibDecoder
class.preview: The dart-io.ZLibDecoder is used by dart-io.ZLibCodec and dart-io.GZipCodec to decompress data.

class.name: ZLibEncoder
class.preview: The dart-io.ZLibEncoder encoder is used by dart-io.ZLibCodec and dart-io.GZipCodec to compress data.

class.name: GZipCodec
class.preview: The dart-io.GZipCodec encodes raw bytes to GZip compressed bytes and decodes GZip compressed bytes to raw bytes.

class.name: ZLibCodec
class.preview: The dart-io.ZLibCodec encodes raw bytes to ZLib compressed bytes and decodes ZLib compressed bytes to raw bytes.

class.name: ZLibOption
class.preview: Exposes ZLib options for input parameters.

class.name: OSError
class.preview: An dart-io.OSError object holds information about an error from the operating system.

class.name: BytesBuilder
class.preview: Builds a list of bytes, allowing bytes and lists of bytes to be added at the end.

error.name: CertificateException
error.preview: An exception that happens in the handshake phase of establishing a secure network connection, when looking up or verifying a certificate.

error.name: HandshakeException
error.preview: An exception that happens in the handshake phase of establishing a secure network connection.

error.name: TlsException
error.preview: A secure networking exception caused by a failure in the TLS/SSL protocol.

error.name: FileSystemException
error.preview: Exception thrown when a file operation fails.

error.name: IOException
error.preview: Base class for all IO related exceptions.
